content.raw:
Okay, and now I know why I didn't use `target_include_directories(...)`. It gives the following error:

```
CMake Error at /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/cmake/ignition-cmake0/cmake0/IgnImportTarget.cmake:109 (target_include_directories):
  target_include_directories called with non-compilable target type
Call Stack (most recent call first):
  /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/cmake/ignition-cmake0/cmake0/IgnPkgConfig.cmake:108 (ign_import_target)
  /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/cmake/ignition-cmake0/cmake0/IgnPkgConfig.cmake:45 (ign_pkg_check_modules_quiet)
  /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/cmake/ignition-cmake0/cmake0/FindAVUTIL.cmake:19 (ign_pkg_check_modules)
  /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/cmake/ignition-cmake0/cmake0/IgnUtils.cmake:145 (find_package)
  CMakeLists.txt:101 (ign_find_package)
```

There has already been a discussion about this [on kitware](https://gitlab.kitware.com/cmake/cmake/issues/15689), and a solution seems to [have been merged](https://gitlab.kitware.com/cmake/cmake/merge_requests/1264), but I doubt it will be available to us until a much later version of cmake (as of [the 3.10 documentation](https://cmake.org/cmake/help/v3.10/command/target_include_directories.html), you still cannot use `target_include_directories(~)` on an imported target).

I'll see if I can figure out how to set this property for lists in a way that cmake is happy with.

There has already been a discussion about this on kitware, and a solution seems to have been merged, but I doubt it will be available to us until a much later version of cmake (as of the 3.10 documentation, you still cannot use target_include_directories(~) on an imported target).

I'll see if I can figure out how to set this property for lists in a way that cmake is happy with.
